body:
Current implementation:
`parse("null , , empty , ''")` yields `"null"`, `null`, `"empty"`, and `null` 

With `setEmptyValue("")`:
`parse("null , , empty , ''")` would result in `"null"`, `null`, `"empty"`, and `""`

My understanding was that one could specify an _empty string_ by supplying two adjacent single-quotes.

So, if that's not the case, then I am for changing the configuration to make it so.

issue.title: CSV parser returns an empty String instead of null

milestone.title: 5.0 RC3
milestone.description: Themes: configuration parameters and bug fixes.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

When using `@CsvSource` or `@CsvFileSource` in a parameterized test, if the CSV parser does not read any character from the input, and the input is within quotes, an empty string `""` is returned instead of `null`.

Closes #1014

issue.title: Level of documentation in the JavaDoc

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Copied comment from @smoyer64  in #1014:

> Looking at the section of the users guide for parameterized tests, there's a lot of great information which is exactly the sort of thing I'd like to see when my IDE pops up the javadocs for @CsvSource. Unfortunately, those javadocs simply link back to the users guide for the important stuff.

> I do think it's important to have a good users guide for those who are jumping into junit5 but I believe that those who are heavy users will appreciate the javadocs being complete and stand-alone. It's a lot more work to keep up-to-date if the information is in both places but I believe for things like this, it's important - kind of like date and regex format descriptions in the Java SE javadocs.

## Deliverables

- [ ] Enhance Javadoc with more details, examples and other "important stuff"

issue.title: Ensure JavaDoc provides complete examples and references for JUnit 5 power users

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Users who are familiar with JUnit 5 will still rely on the javadocs displayed by their IDE for reference information.  One example of where the javadocs could be more helpful is the ```@CsvSource``` annotation.  The user's guide has an extremely useful paragraph for this ```@ArgumentSource``` that describes how to use single quotes as well as how to produce null values versus empty String objects.  The table referenced in the users guide would definitely be a bonus.

Note that I'm not proposing the users guide move completely into the javadocs (e.g. Mockito) and that I recognize this adds housekeeping complexity to ensure that the javadocs and users guide don't contradict each other.  But in thinking about how I program with libraries I know well, there are definitely still javadoc pages that I rely on (e.g. the Java SE Pattern and SimpleDateFormat javadocs)

- (X) **Feature request.** Update the javadocs for types that commonly require looking at reference information.  This request could be limited to the ```junit-jupiter-api``` and ```junit-jupiter-params``` packages which would be sufficient to provide documentation to both test and extension writers.

## Deliverables

- [ ] CsvSource
- [ ] CsvFileSource
- [ ] ...

*Prompted by the discussion on #1014*
